timeline.bodyText:
I've already canonicalised the method of finding this selector as you can see in the "Refine Search by Owner" block, getOwnerFilter().
If this test won't be joining the block, then we should move that function out into a helper file.
But you'll also note I've further standardised the approach with a generic function for grabbing the selectors #2172. Although they are using the IDs (so not something the user can see), I feel that makes it more robust.
And as a side note, where possible we should use the language strings, not string literals.
timeline.author: edalex-ian

timeline.bodyText:
I'm not sure this is correct. As ownerSelector is an Element instance that belonged to a previously rendered DOM. As a result, you really should be running the getter again. Ideally ownerSelector would be a function, like my aforementioned getOwnerFilter - renamed getOwnerSelector in #2172 .
So as a result, you're getting a false positive here - and pretty well always would even if the control was there. To check that though, you could comment out your mocking of the mockSearchSettings value.
timeline.author: edalex-ian
edalex-ian

timeline.bodyText: Should we make this optional, so it can kind of default to false?
timeline.author: edalex-ian

timeline.bodyText: hmmmm, because these are getting changed via an effect, if the default is true but then the server says false will there be a momentary rendering of them? (I think I've seen this kind of visual effect with how we show the settings - they initially render in one state, and then swap to what we get from the server.) Maybe none should be rendered until we've heard from the server to ensure smooth UX - rather than disappearing controls.
timeline.author: edalex-ian

replies.bodyText: So it turns out they all currently have a default of false and as a result this should just be a case of a delay in showing the components. That should be AOK. 👍

timeline.message: Tweak RefineSearchPanel's props and its return.

Don't use default Search settings in SearchPage.

If refine controls are disabled, they still appear when the page
is initially rendered. And after Search settings are retrieved
they will disappear. So we want to avoid this bad visual effect.

Refactor tests which check Refine Search controls' visibility

1. Use parameterised test to reduce code duplication; and
2. Add a new function to find HTML element by custom attributes
   without throwing errors; and
3. A few tidy ups for the test.
